_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Cargill Distribution Center chemical accident prevention and emergency response policies for ammonia refrigeration involve the development of this Risk Management Program and Plan (?RMP?) which has a primary objective of preventing an accidental  release of ammonia, and in the event there is one, minimize the consequences of a release.



The stationary source subject to this RMP is Cargill?s refrigeration warehousing and storage facility located in Mt. Crawford, Virginia.  The facility has two interconnected refrigeration systems which contain anhydrous ammonia, a regulated substance under the RMP regulations.



The location has prepared worst case and alternative case release scenarios using the ALOHA air dispersion modeling software which calculates the distance to the toxic endpoints. 



In accordance with RMP regulations, the general accidental release prevention program for this facility?s ammonia refrigeration system is comprised of the following components: process safety information, process hazard analysis, operating procedures, operator training, procedures for maintaining mechanical integrity, procedures for managing system changes, pre-start up safety review procedures, procedures for investigating release incidents, and hot work permit protocols.  This program was developed with the participation of the affected employees, and will be periodically audited for compliance required by the RMP regulations.  In addition, the facility has in place procedures for notifying contractors and their employees of the hazards of the system.  Chemical specific prevention steps are included within the program, including engineering and administration controls designed to prevent and minimize accidental releases.  



In the five years preceding the submittal of this RMP, this facility has not had any accidental releases of ammonia which have resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, shelteri

ng in place, property damage, or environmental damage.
